title: Release 0.8-rc0
body:
- [x] Changelog
- [x] Checking documentation

title: Add transparent option to the WindowMode settings.
body: This very simple PR just adds a transparent option in WindowMode to allow for transparent windows.

title: Improve sub-context passing ergonomics
body:
this allows passing just `ctx` to functions that take sub-contexts.
You can still split borrow with a slightly uglier construction: `&(&ctx.fs, &ctx.gfx)`.
I think something like 99.9% of users won't ever have to split borrow so in my opinion, this is a good trade-off.

title: Clamp the scissor rect to canvas bounds before applying
body: Closes #1033.

title: Add scissor_rect to canvas
body: Closes #603

title: Provide access to keyboard scancodes
body:
Not sure if this is something that ggez would like, but opening this MR because it's something I've needed for my project.

Basically, this exposes the winit scancodes to the EventHandler should the developer want access to them. They can use these codes to implement support for non US QWERTY keyboards.

Have added it as a seperate event hook so that existing code and guides can use the "simple" function in case they don't need scancodes.

I'm also not a keyboard expert, so there's probably much better ways to go about doing this!

===

Extend the EventHandler trait to include key up/down events that have a
scancode. This can be used by developers to have layout-independant key
bindings.

title: Update dependencies
body:
- `image` to `0.24`
- `rodio` to `0.15`
- `zip` to `0.6`

title: Relax `EventHandler` error implementations
body:
Solves part of #1021. This PR changes the limitations imposed to the error type parameter of `EventHandler`, only imposing that it needs `Debug`, and not a full `Error` implementation. This allows using `Box<dyn std::error::Error>` as well as `anyhow::Error` as the error type.

This change is non-breaking as it only relaxes an imposed condition.

body:
- Closes #1012
- Closes #962
- Closes #562
- Closes #1007

- Closes #1003

title: Use subcontexts directly instead of free functions
body:
Deprecates the old free functions and uses the subcontexts directly, as mentioned in #1012 and discussed in the Matrix room. WIP.

Note: The graphical context hasn't been refactored since the changes would be overwritten by the WGPU PR anyways.

title: Add `SpriteBatch::image()`
body: I don't see any reason why SpriteBatch's `image` member should be private to reads, so I've added a read-only property for it.

title: Add h1v3 to the list of projects
Fix misnaming of `EventLoop` in HelloGgez guide
body: The text and link were referring to `EventsLoop`, which seems to have been its name prior to winit 0.20.0.

title: Changed bare url to automatic for rustdoc
Exposed rodio API for skipping first part of a sample
body:
Hi!  I just happened to need this little bit of rodio API, and it seemed like the easiest way to get it was to patch ggez.  I don't know if you'd consider it too cluttered to expose this in ggez's API, but since it's so tiny, I figured I might as well just submit the pull request and let you decide.

You can read about the rodio method being called here: https://docs.rs/rodio/0.14.0/rodio/source/trait.Source.html#method.skip_duration .  Basically, it just skips the first part of a sound source.  This can be useful, for example,

* If you're processing an audio event "late" due to networking delays, but you want to keep the audio in-sync with the visuals
* If you want to play only the latter part of a sound effect
* If you want to start playing a piece of music partway in

All the same, it's a bit niche, and these use cases might be better covered by just using rodio directly.  Since calling `skip_duration` wraps the entire sound sample iterator in a `SkipDuration` iterator, this might add a small overhead to any audio being played, but it's probably not a big deal, and it's consistent with how the ggez interface exposes other rodio features.

title: Fix zip `read_dir` deeper than one level in Windows
body:
Windows uses `\\` instead of `/` as the delimiter for Path, but since the index of zip returns the `/` delimiter, it did not detect the existence of the directory correctly when compared with `starts_with()` in `read_dir()`.
By using `sanitize_path_for_zip()`, `\\` is converted to `/` and the path is sanitized.

Also fix that the directory passed as an argument to `read_dir()` is not included in the iterator to make it work the same as NonZip.

In NonZip's read_dir, `read_dir("/foobar/")` returns `/foobar/file.ext` and so on.
In Zip's read_dir, when `read_dir("/foobar/")` is used, it returns `foobar/file.ext` without the leading `/`.
Zip and NonZip don't match, so the Zip process is now adapted to NonZip and returns the file with `/` at the beginning.

title: Modified the input module somewhat
body:
I've added some functions to the keyboard and mouse contexts that can detect whether a button is pressed/released on a certain frame (i.e., pressed this frame but released last frame and vice versa). I also changed the mouse state to be represented with a HashSet, just to keep it consistent with the keyboard.

This requires an extra variable in `KeyboardContext` and `MouseContext` that represents the state of the keyboard/mouse on the previous frame. Alternatively you could represent the state as a `HashMap<KeyCode, (bool, bool)>`, but I don't know if changing this each frame would be more or less efficient than just cloning to a new variable.

title: Update dependencies
body:
- `winit` to `0.26`
- `glutin` to `0.28`
- `directories` to `4.0`

**Please only open PRs that are based on and aimed towards the `devel` branch**

**For more information take a look at [the contribution guide](./CONTRIBUTING.md)**

title: Touch event
body: I needed access to the touch event for a project I am doing with a raspberry pi. Rather than writing a custom event loop, this PR will give developers access to the touch events in the same way that we can with mouse & keyboard events.

title: added error handling to the remaining EventHandler methods
body:
Closes #800

This PR adds the same error handling capabilities that are currently provided for `EventHandler::draw` and `EventHandler::update` to all the remaining methods of `EventHandler`.

This excludes `EventHandler::on_error`, for which adding this could lead to infinite recursion if a user isn't careful. Also it seems a bit silly to add error handling to the error handling function itself, as you'd still need to handle errors caused by the error handling inside that function anyway.

title: implemented MSAA on canvases via a fragment shader workaround
body:
I followed the inspiration from https://github.com/gfx-rs/gfx/issues/1024 to implement a fragment shader workaround for MSAA on canvases.

It doesn't work on GLES though, as it doesn't have `sampler2DMS`, so the shader won't work. But it compiles and it doesn't crash. On my system multi-sampled canvases simply do not get drawn on GLES.

To write `Canvas::resolve` (which applies the fragment shader workaround) I had to lose `CanvasGeneric`, because `resolve` now needs to be called before `to_rgba8` to make sure the image is up to date and `resolve` needs to change the `out` pipe, which is part of `gfx_device_gl::Resources`, but not of `S::Resources` yet.

As we'll probably move on to `wgpu` in the future it shouldn't matter much though. When we do so we'll probably get rid of the generics anyway (as `wgpu` in itself is really generic enough already and noone wants to write a second graphics backend for ggez anyway, I think; if someone desires to do so, forking ggez might really be the more sane option anyway IMO).

If there was some elegant way though to keep `CanvasGeneric` and still implement `resolve` I'd of course prefer that.

title: Re-export winit
body: Actually add a re-export of `winit` as this was previously missing. It's mentioned in `context.rs` that "we re-export winit" but this currently isn't the case. This PR just adds `ggez::winit`.

title: Small things
body: added a warning about multisampling on canvases, polished two examples a little and added a link to a statically hosted version of the animation example to the readme

title: Fix conversion of linear color to sRGB
body: Per https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Srgb#From_CIE_XYZ_to_sRGB , you have to subtract 0.055 from the color value after multiplying and exponentiating in order to properly invert the sRGB gamma function.  You can verify that the conversion is correct here: https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=c2aedead960001921875514d371bea5e

title: Adapted `MeshBatch` behavior to match `SpriteBatch`
body:
changed `MeshBatch` to respect `DrawParam::offset` as a relative offset, instead of an absolute one;

changed `MeshBatch::dimensions` to return a rectangle containing all mesh instances;

title: Add methods to obtain references to internal sprite data in SpriteBatch
body:
There is currently no way, as far as I know, to remove elements from the sprite batch and this would give a decent way of doing that.

This is modeled after the same methods in MeshBatch, docstring and all. The naming could probably use some bikeshedding.

title: added support for the tga image format
body: Addresses #973

title: changed/fixed mouse delta behavior
body:
This PR addresses #977.

I basically just implemented my proposal there, fixing `mouse::delta`, but also introducing possible differences between `mouse::delta` and the `dx`, `dy` values returned by `mouse_motion_event`s.

title: Added an example showcasing animation with keyframe
body:
Based on the discussion in #910 I finally made an example showcasing both tween and frame-by-frame animations using keyframe.

It... works, but there's some code duplication, that I'd really like to get rid off.
But after fiddling with generics for some time I now think the only option would be to use macros to do that, but I'm unsure as to whether we'd want to do that, since we probably don't want to force new (Rust) users to read macro code in order to understand the example.

But maybe I'm missing something.

title: Fixed an issue that prevented opening resources.zip files deeper than one level in Windows environments.
body:
Fixed a problem that prevented opening files deeper than one level in resources.zip on Windows.

When reading a Zip file, it was using the `to_str()` string of `PathBuf` as index.
However, on Windows, `to_str()` on a `PathBuf` would use `\\` as the separator.
For example, `foo\\bar.txt`.

This prevented us from reading the contents of the resources.zip file more than one level deep under Windows, which would require a separator.

In this PR, when reading zip files, instead of using `to_str()` in `PathBuf`, using  `sanitize_path_for_zip`, which a modified version of `sanitize_path`, to generate a `/` delimited path using a string.

This makes it possible to use resources.zip in Windows environments.

title: Allow renaming of resources and resources.zip
body:
Hi!

This is a PR for an additional feature as the title suggests.

I wanted to change the name of `resources.zip` to `data`.
I personally think it's cooler to have `data` with no extension next to the exe than to have a file with a `.zip` extension next to it.
Of course, I understand that hiding the extension does not lead to any kind of encryption.
It's just to make it look cool, nothing more.

I added `resources_dir_name` and `resources_zip_name` as arguments when building the filesystem.
I added a method to ContextBuilder to change this setting.
The default values are set to `resources` and `resources.zip`, which are the same as before, respectively.

As a limitation, unfortunately, this setting cannot be written in `conf.toml`, because `conf.toml` must be in resources, and can only be used after the resources directory has been determined.
Therefore, this setting can only be changed via the `ContextBuilder` method.

I understand that more configuration increases complexity and may threaten "make good games, easily".
However, I believe that adding this setting will not add too much complexity since the default setting is to use the existing `resources` ans `resources.zip`.
If there are any problems, I will withdraw this PR.

Thank you for your patience.
Finally, thanks for the awesome crate!

title: Make most of the `filesystem` functions take `&Context`.
body:
Most of these functions do not need to take `&mut Context` and can simply
take `&Context` instead. This is helpful since there are some scenarios
where you want `&Context`s, such as when passing the same context to a
bunch of closures that all want to read a file and don't need mutability.

Fixes #967

title: Fixes memory leak in to_rgba8 and screenshot
body:
This fixes the memory leak by just using the global command buffer instead of creating a "local" new one, which is leaky.

I also added a download buffer handle to the gfx context, to avoid possibly recreating it all the time.
This is probably not important, but it's the first thing I tried and it works and it probably improves performance for use cases like #958, so why not keep it.

title: Everyone think we're good to make this RC2?
body: This commit just updates the Cargo.toml and such.

title: EventHandler Error handling
body:
This is a first shot at fixing #800.
Instead of having to write error handling wrappers for each EventHandler function one can now just implement `EventHandler::on_error` to achieve customized error handling.

This still doesn't give users much freedom to handle their own kinds of errors though. Their only option for this, at this point, is to create a `GameError::CustomError(String)`, which is much better than nothing, but not ideal yet.

title: Add MacOS explaination to building guide.
body: Resolves #900 ; issues like that are best considered bugs in the documentation.  They looked for info in the correct spot and it wasn't there, so the program we wrote for humans to execute was incomplete.

body:
I don't see why it even needs to do that.
Fixes #677

title: Snake example: Use the library's timer rather than manual time tracking
body:
Although it works for the example, manually tracking the time is not generally correct, as the game time can differ from the system time.

Using the library's timer also simplifies the code.

title: Snake example: Simplify non-negative modulo computation, by using rem_euclid() API
body:
The functionality previously implemented manually, via ModuloSigned trait, is actually already existing in the Rust APIs - [rem_euclid()](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/primitive.i16.html#method.rem_euclid).

While using traits is always cool™, it's best to reduce the cognitive overhead on the readers, especially considering that this is an example for beginners.

If you render to a canvas that has a different aspect ratio than

title: Added my project to the 0.5.x list
Bump lyon to 0.17.5
body:
Relies on https://github.com/ggez/ggez/pull/917 so that CI succeeds.

* The `basic_shapes` module was removed as described [here](https://github.com/nical/lyon/issues/606), so most of the changes are related to using `FillTesselator` and `StrokeTesselator` instead.
* `BasicVertexConstructor` was also removed, meaning that the only way to add vertices to `BufferedBuilders` is as part of a stroke or fill. The only place where that API was relied on was in `MeshBuilder.triangles`, so I just inserted the vertices directly into the `VertexBuffers`.

title: Fix build errors
body:
* Insert missing comma
* Remove unused import of `TryFrom`
* `NumSamples::try_from` was changed from a u32 to a u8, so the `graphics_settings.rs` example
needs to be updated accordingly.
* `clippy` was complaining about acronyms like `OpenGL`, `OpenGLES`, `VFS`, and `OverlayFS` being incorrectly CamelCased. 
* Backticks were being used in a section header to format `ggez::graphics`
as code. While this looked good, the skeptic automated markdown tests
do not parse backticked strings as names, so the section header was
parsed as an empty string. This resulted in test names with two 
underscores (`__`) because there was no section to separate them, which 
was flagged by `cargo check` as poorly typed snake_case.
* clippy recommends implementing `From` instead of `Into` for converting 
`u8` to `NumSamples`, as `From` gives you `Into` for free, but the reverse 
is not true.
https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#from_over_into
* Remove useless type conversions.

body: Couldn't build the basic project template provided in the README.md, this change was needed.

title: Scale Image correctly when using Transform::Matrix
body:
When currently drawing an `Image` while using `Transform::Matrix` instead of `Transform::Values`, the output is rendered way too small. This PR adds the required scale factor to get the correct image size.

Furthermore, it adds a method `transform` to `DrawParam`.

Fixes #894.

title: ❌️ -> ✅️: Fix CI Failures due to Clippy Lints
body:
I noticed that the CI is not passing due to Clippy, and thought I would try to get it green again. 😁

This will require a change to your Github Actions to use a slightly different clippy command (see below) so we don't pull in linting issues from dependencies, but when that is altered, I'm hoping the code changes I have made should allow it to pass.

I've made the changes pretty naïvely in order to get the lints passing (lots of `#[allow(...)]`). Perhaps you'd prefer to change the projects linting settings instead of this, but hopefully this is a good starting point. 🙂

---

The command to use in the Github Actions:
```
cargo clippy --all-targets --package ggez -- -D warnings
```

title: forced the window dimensions to be physical not logical
body:
The initial coordinate system was calculated based on the **logical** window size, while we actually want it to match the **physical** window size, so I changed it.
I also added some explanation to the input example, since users should be aware that they may need to think about such things.

inspired by / solving #883

title: fixed drawing transformation matrix
body:
This pull request fixes how the transformation matrix is calculated, making offset work as intended.
For more details and examples of the problematic behavior see #879.

title: Removing NumSamples::Zero
body:
I think that the fix for #552 is invalid. I haven't been able to gather much information about multisampling but looking at the comments from graphics/canvas.rs:108 and graphics/mod.rs:498, It seems that 1 sample is the true no-sampling mode. The Zero variant causes unnecessary confusion and incoherent errors. As this would unfix #552, I included a possible alternative fix where sample count of 1 gets passed as 0 to glutin. 
I Haven't tested it as I am not that familiar with how the output should look.

Closes #720 as it will no longer be possible to use Zero

title: Glyph position
body:
Closes #849 and closes #738 with something like
```rust
self.glyph_positions(context)
    .iter()
    .for_each(|glyph_position| println!("There's a glyph at {:?}!", glyph_position));
```

title: Remove transform stack
body:
This stops pretending that I want a transform stack inside ggez itself and makes it easier for people to just write their own external to it.  Hopefully removing a fair few bugs and confusion.  Resolves #369 .

Paging @PsichiX for awareness/review.

title: Remove the docs for pipe in graphics::pipe
Update and draw only on MainEventsCleared.
body:
I think this was left over by some sort of merge mistake? d2a1fe9 moved
state.update() and state.draw() into the MainEventsCleared handler,
where they should be, but somehow they wound up outside again.  Anyway,
this fixes FPS issues in astroblasto on my machine.

The callback passed to event_loop.run() is called with every single event, so anything that's written after the match statement should also get executed with each event.  Code meant to run _after_ the event queue has finished processing should be in the MainEventsCleared handler, assuming I understand the way that the new winit event loop works.

title: Allow Custom Gamepads
body:
With the addition of the `GilrsGamepadContext::from()` method, developers can now create any `Gilrs` type, change it to a `GilrsGamepadContext` type, and then do
```ctx.gamepad_context = Box::new(GilrsGamepadContext::from(gilrs));```
to use their custom `Gilrs` type.

The reason this is important is that it allows developers to use Gilrs methods that aren't currently accessible through ggez, like the `add_mappings()` method (see https://docs.rs/gilrs/0.7.4/gilrs/struct.GilrsBuilder.html#method.add_mappings). That specific example allows for custom gamepad mappings to be added in, which most importantly allows developers to read the contents of a file that has been filled with gilrs mapping strings and use them in their ggez project, which makes for easy gamepad setup even if the gamepad isn't automatically supported (automatically supported controllers: https://github.com/gabomdq/gamecontrollerdb/blob/c5992e0edc141be1fd0764c810792b4ead26e25c/gamecontrollerdb.txt) using a program such as this: https://generalarcade.com/gamepadtool/.

title: Iss640
body:
Fix for issue #640 

Instead of returning a bool, check_update_time() will now return a GameResult<bool>. If called more than MAX_INCREMENTAL_UPDATES times per call to update(), it will return TimeCatchupError, which is a new GameError I added for this purpose. Otherwise, check_update_time() returns Ok(true/false) as it did before. All the examples and documentation should be updated accordingly.

Let me know if there are any issues/changes that you would like me to make
